speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We’ll hear argument first today in Whitman versus Department of Transportation. Ms. Karlan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We’re not bound by that concession. If that’s a jurisdictional question, doesn’t matter whether the Government conceded it or not, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That’s a different question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I still think it’s whether because I don’t agree with the Government. Can I do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So that is the question. I mean, the question is open whether there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Was it raised? Was that objection, the jurisdictional question, raised in the briefs and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But our cases say that where we don’t speak to a jurisdictional question, it is not regarded as having been decided. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even -- even if you assume that Von Raab decided it, you have a quite different situation here. The issue isn’t whether there will be any judicial review. The issue is whether there will be judicial review for the minor grievances, even if they happen to involve a constitutional issue, that are -- that are not -- for which judicial review was not provided. Any major employee action -- judicial review, as I understand it, is available, and it is only relatively insignificant actions for which judicial review is not available. Isn’t that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He could have refused -- he could have refused the search, in which case if there was any significant personnel action taken against him for refusing it, he would have had judicial review of whether the search was constitutional or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That’s often the case where -- where, in -- in order to challenge a governmental action, you -- you have to be willing to -- to go to court by resisting it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even though if -- if -- do you concede that if he had, for example, refused the testing and been fired and it was a major personnel action, he would have to go through the statutory procedures before bringing that -- the constitutional claim on review of those administrative procedures?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, doesn’t it seem odd -- and this is sort of the logic of -- in Fausto and some of the other cases -- that when you have a major action, you have to exhaust before you can go into court, but if you have something that doesn’t qualify as a major adverse action, you get to go to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 court right away?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that search was a consequence of his employment. It -- this wasn’t a search of a -- of a citizen who had no connection with the Government. It was a search that he was required to submit to as an employee. So to -- to describe it as unrelated to employee action seems to me unrealistic. The only reason he submitted to it was that if he didn’t, he would have -- he would have been subject to an employee action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you think it becomes unconstitutional when -- when you have one more test? What did it become unconstitutional? The first test was not unconstitutional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: How many tests did he have?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Over what period of time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So it’s maybe three -- three a year? Is that what it was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And that’s unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, somebody will be if 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 it’s random. If you have thousands of people, somebody will be if it is random. If there were nobody who was picked seven times, that would show it wasn’t random. So, you know --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- whether he has a good constitutional claim here I guess is rather doubtful --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What are they? How many people are there? How many people are tested if you try to calculate it? How many --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in the Federal Government?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All you do is you get a bell curve and you ask the Library of Congress and they’ll 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 do it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No. It’s -- it’s not hard to do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it’s not hard to do. You just ask someone at Stanford. They’ll do it for you. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Regardless, this is beside the point. I -- all right. Can I -- I just want you at some point to get to not just the constitutional question. Maybe he can go in and raise his claim. I don’t know if he should have exhausted or not, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I find it hard, in reading this, to believe the following. Like any other worker, I mean, normally you have a collective 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 bargaining agreement, and the union takes up your minor thing. And here, what you’re saying is although if it’s a major thing, like a personnel action, there’s a special thing where you get in -- you know, you -- you get into court way down the road. It’s very complicated. This individual, even though he classifies it as a grievance where the union is supposed to take it up and the union tells him we’re not going to take it up, we don’t believe in your claim, that then he can run in to a Federal judge. Now, that -- that I find surprising, and I’d like you to explain how in your theory that works.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought your position, Ms. Karlan, was that he doesn’t even have to ask the union. Justice Breyer is presenting a scenario where 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 he asks the union and the union says we’ve got better things to do with our money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I think your position is he doesn’t have to ask at all. He can go directly into Federal court under 1331.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, why -- why can’t he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why not? Because my -- when I first looked at this, I thought, well, this is the kind of thing that should have been -- should have been resolved at the grievance level, it shouldn’t have even have to get to arbitration if he’s right. He 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 wants a survey to see if he’s being picked on. If he is, there would be redress. So it seemed like this was the kind of complaint that was best handled in that kind of procedure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but that simply means that the grievance procedure is more valuable in this case than merely talking to his supervisor. And -- and the -- the issue -- maybe -- maybe we’re missing it, but the issue is why isn’t there a very good reason to require him to go through the grievance procedure, number one, to -- to cut down on needless Federal court actions and, number two, under the -- sort of the general policy of favoring what collective bargaining agreements negotiate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but -- no -- no question. That would be an easier case. But why shouldn’t we require an exhaustion for those two reasons and maybe others?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: He may not have any right to it, but in fact, he may get some relief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The union may say, okay, we’re going to take this one up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why isn’t the thing to do here -- I -- I see that you are raising a significant question in respect to -- at least in my view, in respect to the -- an action that violates a regulation that violates a statute. Leave the Constitution aside, but it might violate a number of practices, good practices, et cetera. But why isn’t focusing on that the thing for the plaintiff here to do is he goes to the union -- I’m just reading from page 6 and 7 of your brief -- and he says, I would like you to invoke arbitration? And they might do it. Now, if they do it and it comes out a way they don’t like, he then -- they might file exceptions and they might 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 win. But what you’re worried about is if they don’t win or if they don’t do it, they can go to court only if it involved an unfair labor practice or a major adverse personnel action. That’s what’s worrying you, I take it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why isn’t it, at that stage if he doesn’t get into court, you then say that that isn’t true? They should be able to come to court in other instances as well, making the same kinds of arguments that you’re making now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You -- you -- I -- I believe that there are millions of instances, perhaps. Now, I’m -- when I think something like this, I’m quite often wrong. But I thought that the reason that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 exhaustion is required is not always because statutes require it. It’s partly because of the word final in the APA, which applies here as well, and it’s also because of the common law of administrative law that requires people to exhaust their remedies.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, but the -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the whole right to -- to go into court with a constitutional claim is absent from the statute. And -- and so we may as well get hung for a sheep as a lamb. If -- if we’re going to recognize the one, I don’t see that we’re going too much further in -- in saying it’s got to be conditional on the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the grievance procedure covers it, and you took pains to point out to us that when you go to the grievance procedure, you’re not necessarily entitled to findings and -- and written 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 conclusions, et cetera. But there’s a reason for that. The reason for that is that these things can be very, very minor. So now you’re saying that just because of -- the grievance procedure doesn’t entitle you necessarily to findings, et cetera, that you can go into court. But the only reason you don’t get those findings is because we know, going in, that they’re so minor. So now the most minor things go to court. That seems very anomalous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I have to interrupt you. What is the Fourth Amendment violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: As I understand, the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 allegations are that there was random procedure in effect, and he thinks maybe he’s been tested more frequently than some other people. That’s all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, but as I understand it, the -- the system as a whole is not challenged as violating the Fourth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: By having him take more tests than would be produced by a purely random selection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Have we ever said that’s a Fourth Amendment violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If the computer malfunctions, that’s a Fourth Amendment violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But the relief that he requested was to do a little more testing to see whether he was being tested more than the average person, as I understand it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which is not -- did not seem to me to be alleging a violation of the Fourth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. -- Ms. Karlan, if this is indeed serious, are you sure that it’s not a personnel action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There is a residual category 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 in the definition of personnel action which says, any other significant change in duties, responsibilities, or working conditions. That’s the residual category. But one of the specifically named categories, before you get to that, is a decision to order psychiatric testing. Now, if that kind of a decision could be a personnel action, why couldn’t a decision to conduct -- to conduct a drug test be considered a personnel action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I’m not adding it. There’s a residual category at the end: or any other significant change in duties, responsibilities, or working conditions. I consider this -- you consider it a significant change in working conditions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And he thought he didn’t have to undergo drug testing, and what do you know? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 He’s being picked on for drug testing all the time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why then would a decision to order psychiatric testing qualify? Because it says, or any other. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Significant change in duties, responsibilities, or working conditions. The implication is that a decision to order psychiatric testing is a significant change in duties, responsibilities, or -- or working conditions. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It’s always good to be safe.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. -- Ms. Karlan, you have a -- a statutory claim that essentially mirrors the constitutional claim. The statute requires the testing to be random and impartial. If we think there’s a difference between the constitutional claims and statutory claims with respect to their treatment under the CSRA, how do you handle that? Does he have to exhaust the statutory claim but not the constitutional one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you -- you agree with 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the Government on that, that he can never get review of the statutory claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, don’t -- don’t appeal to them on a -- on a point on which you don’t agree with them. I mean --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I still don’t understand how they proceed. Does he have to bring -- can he go right into court on the constitutional claim even if the statutory claim has to go through the grievance procedure?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the identical claims have to proceed under two different routes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Stewart.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, can I just ask one question? Because I didn’t quite follow it. I thought you were describing a major personnel action in -- in your description of the administrative review. But if this is a minor or whatever, a lesser review, would there have been an avenue through the administrative agency?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Through the collective bargaining --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But then supposing the union is unwilling to grieve or take it up or he fails, then what happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And it would be in the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So your difference -- what’s separating you and Whitman, it seems, is a question of timing. The action that you’re describing that would come at the end, after he’s used the administrative process, is the same one that he is seeking to bring at the front end. That is, it’s a 1331 action --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- and -- and it’s based on the Government’s waiver of sovereign immunity for nonmonetary claims.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, you know, you have here a statute in which Congress, with malice aforethought, very clearly provides for judicial review of any major personnel actions and does not provide for judicial review of what it had regarded as insignificant personnel actions. I can understand the position, although I don’t agree with it, that the constitutional provision which says Congress can -- can make exceptions to the jurisdiction of the Federal courts should not be interpreted to exclude significant constitutional claims. But when Congress has gone to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the trouble of providing for judicial review of any claims that are significant and just saying any other insignificant action, even though a constitutional violation is alleged in connection with it, if in fact it does not harm you that much, we’re not going to allow judicial review, what is -- what is wrong with that? It seems to me that’s what Congress has said and -- and you’re creating a scheme that simply contradicts what Congress plainly said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did any of them involve a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- -- situation in which Congress took the pain to separate significant actions from insignificant actions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, some of them involve deportation and, you know, major -- major actions. This is a case where Congress has -- has carefully tried to say these are major actions for which you should be able to get into the courts. And these other things -- you -- you have these administrative remedies, but that’s the end of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I’m -- I’m not sure what the congressional intent would be to bifurcate the constitutional and the statutory claims, especially if they’re the same thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that’s what -- that’s what you’re asking us to say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But if -- if -- under -- under your explanation of how the system works, you go 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to district court with a constitutional claim. He’s -- he -- the district court doesn’t have to reach the statutory claim first?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that’s what I mean. This is a very odd system where you have to immediately go to the constitutional claim and you’re foreclosed from looking at the statutory claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought your position on the statute was that it doesn’t afford a right of action, that it was just an instruction to the Secretary. Maybe I misread your position on the statute. We’re talking about 45-1048?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that the Government’s position was there’s no right of action under that statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So I guess you’re saying, as to the constitutional claim, it’s obvious they have to exhaust. There’s no reason why they don’t have to exhaust in respect to the 12th test, which has already occurred, and in respect to the 15th, which might be threatened, if it does come about that it’s threatened, they can go in, I guess, under 705 of the APA and ask for an injunction. Any reason they couldn’t do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. What they do is they follow, like any other agency action. An agency action has taken place. I think it’s unconstitutional 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 or you do. We exhaust our remedies and then get to court at the end of the day and make our claim. An agency action is threatened. I am threatened with irreparable injury. I can go to court, I think, at the time it’s threatened, and say I want a protective order. I think 705 provides for that specifically. And -- and, therefore, I’m protected. I can’t imagine why they couldn’t do that if they have a -- not just a plausible, but a -- a good claim that it does violate the Constitution and they need the protection. Is there any reason they couldn’t?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, they wouldn’t. Their point is that the very -- availing myself of the administrative remedy will work irreparable harm of -- in violation of my constitutional right. Now, maybe that’s not true, but let’s imagine it’s true. Then couldn’t they go in and ask for a protective order? I thought that you could do that, but I might be wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. And is there any 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- reason that they shouldn’t be able to do that here? Because they are going to say that -- I don’t know they ever can make it out in this case, but they are going to say that my having to go ahead with the number -- test number 15, which, by the way, may never be threatened, but if it is, it will, the very fact that I have to do it, violate an important constitutional right that I need to have protected before undergoing the text -- the test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You think they could not do that under 705. So there is a difference between you on that. As to the statutory claim, I mean, I find -- but others may disagree with this. It’s my personal view that the notion of private right of action in this area simply mixes things up. It’s apples and oranges. It has nothing to do with anything. That if a person, in fact, is adversely affected or aggrieved by a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Government action, he usually, almost always, indeed, can get judicial review eventually. But what you’re saying there I take it is that may be so, but this impliedly says no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, my question is do we have to decide that. Because, after all, this individual may get relief through the statutory procedures that you admit are provided by asking for grievance arbitration. He may, the first time he asks for it, be given a piece of paper that shows him he wasn’t hurt. Or he may have been hurt, and they’ll say we don’t it again. There are a lot of things that can happen. Do we have to decide the issue today of whether if he goes to the union, the union says we won’t arbitrate, or they say we will and they lose and it isn’t as an unfair labor practice -- do we have to decide that issue as to whether a person in those circumstances can then subsequently go into court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So we have to say the easier matter is it’s clear that as to such matters, you must exhaust. It’s so clear that there is no reason for us to decide whether there is an implied repeal of the right at the end of some days to -- to judicial review, a matter which is disfavored in the law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I might. My -- so I don’t know why it wouldn’t be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that was on the view that it was an exclusive remedy. The -- the statute is not written in -- in any way as an exhaustion requirement. It says you’ve got a minor grievance -- issue. You go through the grievance procedure. There is no judicial review at the end of the line. So you would be converting something that Congress wrote to be an exclusive remedy into an exhaustion requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you -- you have picked one way to do that. You say go through the grievance procedure. If there’s a constitutional question remaining, if you haven’t been satisfied, then you bring the action in court. Another way to say is, well, as long as we’re making this up, why not allow the -- the action to proceed at once in court, but then the court to say, I’m going to abstain while you go through the grievance procedure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What’s the second statute? There’s no second statute here. There -- there is your concession of the fact that there has to be judicial review. That’s what’s driving all of this. And -- and generally speaking, when we find something to be unconstitutional, we don’t rewrite a statute so that it will be constitutional. We just say, you know, there 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- has to be judicial review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, if you assume the APA is the remedy -- we’re talking about a district court procedure -- how would you describe the final agency action that would be challenged in that lawsuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Let’s assume that the -- he seeks a grievance, and the union refuses to grieve. And then he then goes into -- into district court under the APA. What would the final agency action be in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Very hard to define.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So what would his relief be? He can untake it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because he can’t damages under the APA.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But -- but here, that’s not this case because he said, and when I complained, they did it again.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But that’s not a final agency action. The threat of another test isn’t a final agency action, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Am I right that the statute as written says you don’t have any judicial review for these kinds of actions? You go through the grievance procedure, win or lose. That’s it. There is no judicial review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The statute does not provide for judicial review --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- as it does in the case of major actions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, if -- if we’re going to tweak the statute, isn’t the least possible tweak -- and perhaps not a tweak at all -- simply to consider this a personnel action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If -- if a decision to order psychiatric testing can be one, why can’t a decision to require drug testing be one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I’m not sure it’s a tweak at all. It -- it just depends on -- on what you consider to be working conditions. And in -- in many contexts, we’ve given the broadest possible interpretation to working conditions.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it would mean you don’t get into court at all then. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even in the -- even if it’s not a major personnel action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What their brief says is that they can go on a personnel, as opposed to major personnel, to the OSC if, and only if, the complaint has to do with whistleblowing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And this doesn’t have to do with whistleblowing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And therefore, even if this were a personnel action, that route to the OSC is not open to them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that true? What do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Stewart, let me just be sure I understand. In the Government’s view, is it a personnel action or is it not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In -- in those circuits which allow these cases to go to courts, has there been any indication that the courts are flooded with a number of these cases or --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Stewart. Ms. Karlan, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it’s not rewriting. I mean -- I mean, it’s perhaps.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. You think -- fine. The -- the -- but the -- the issue it seems that could be dispositive of this, in respect to the non-constitutional claims -- and this is why I want to get your response -- is simply that it is a fair implication from Congress having set up on non- constitutional matters a system of arbitration to require your client to go through that system before 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 seeking to get review of the non-constitutional matters in a Federal district court. Now, that’s the normal rule in administrative law. What is the argument that it wouldn’t apply in your case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now you want us to hold you don’t have judicial review --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- under the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, but the answer -- please, I didn’t mean to cut off your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I want to hear your answer to the question that if I agree with you that on non- constitutional matters, if this system doesn’t work for your client, he gets review in a Federal district court. Suppose I agree with you on that. What is the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 argument against requiring him to exhaust the remedy that is there, namely a request for arbitration --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- as an implication from the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now, is there any other claim -- any other answer to the argument other than they waived it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Did I -- could you give -- give the same answer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in respect to your constitutional claim? Why, given the presence of section 705 of the act --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- one’s -- forget it. MS. KARLAN: Oh, oh. JUSTICE BREYER: Your time is up. That’s -- CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I get to say that. Your time is up. (Laughter.) CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Thank you. MS. KARLAN: Thank you, both. CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: The case is submitted.
